body: Damn, nobody can understand how people in those times perceive life.

As for why some girls are responsive even after death. Well, the depiction in the original novel was plain and dry, with mainly dialogues but almost no emotional beauty. The author of these books once said on Pixiv (now gone), that he wanted to add in some emotional grief and "the beauty of death" into the execution process. This is why these death imminent girls look so pretty and alive as they go towards their death.

The guy who showed up in the end is somewhat a guy in charge, who had a romantic history with He Sanchun. As it turns out, the charge is actually nullified and He Sanchun should not have been executed. He was just inches late to save her from death, and this is what makes the story so dramatic. The project is not active for now as the author is kind of busy but I do hope he gets to finish the series.

Let me explain some things. Basically, this series of executions was an inspiration from a novel called 花将军 by 石砚. The story was about anti-Qing dynasty girls causing trouble and ended up executed. What's special is that there exists a policy at where this all happened, which is for female prisoners with a death sentence, they shall be stripped to fully naked, put on a march tied up on a wooden donkey (a wooden horse-shaped mechanism that tortures both the vagina and anus as it moves forward.) They are then executed publicly with no clothes on. This policy was initially made to stall the execution process in case of any last-minute changes to the charge but eventually evolved and adapted to a tradition. In this book, the girl's name is He Sanchun, who is a pro-Ming dynasty girl that gave the Qing government a load of trouble. She gave herself up to the troops and was sentenced to death, by piercing all the way through. Due to her renowned reputation, the execution was done with respect
